{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2018}} {{redirect|B&H}} {{coord|40.753124|-73.996281|format=dms|display=title}} {{Infobox company | name = B&H Foto & Electronics Corp. | logo = B&H Foto & Electronics Logo.svg | logo_size = 250px | type = [[Retail]] | industry = Retail | foundation = 1973 [[Manhattan|New York, New York]] | location = [[Manhattan]], New York City | locations = 1 | slogan = "You go to B&H!" | products = Cameras, video, film, audio, computers, electronics | homepage = {{official|http://www.bhphotovideo.com/}} }} '''B&H Photo Video''', founded in 1973 and located at 420 [[Ninth Avenue (Manhattan)|Ninth Avenue]] on the corner of [[34th Street (Manhattan)|West 34th Street]] and 9th Avenue in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], is the largest non-chain [[Photography|photo]] and [[video]] equipment retailer in the [[United States]].{{cite news| url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/05340/616255.stm| newspaper= [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]| title=New York camera shop combines 18th-century Jewish traditions and the hottest digital technology| author= Goldman, Adam | date=December 12, 2005| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060516165724/http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/05340/616255.stm| archivedate = May 16, 2006}} B&H conducts business through online e-commerce consumer sales, business to business sales, and its one retail location.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bhphotovideo.com/find/HelpCenter/AboutUs.jsp|title=About B&H {{!}} B&H Photo Video|website=www.bhphotovideo.com|access-date=2018-12-03}} Customers engage with B&H via its websites, retail store, phone sales and customer service, email, and chat channels.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bhphotovideo.com/find/HelpCenter/AboutUs.jsp|title=About B&H {{!}} B&H Photo Video|website=www.bhphotovideo.com|access-date=2018-12-03}} B&H has been frequently recognized as a leader in its industry. According to the [[YouTube]] personality [[Casey Neistat]], B&H is "arguably the greatest photo video store on Planet Earth."{{Citation|last=Neistat|first=Casey|title=this $90 water bottle has a Hi Def Video Camera|date=May 1, 2018|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wglytopH34s&t=95s|access-date=November 20, 2018}} B&H was named the leading online consumer electronics retailer by Consumers Reports for 2018 and has been similarly recognized for the past ten years.{{Cite web|url=https://www.consumerreports.org/cro/electronics-stores.htm|title=Top Electronics store Reviews {{!}} Best Electronics store – Consumer Reports|website=www.consumerreports.org|access-date=2018-12-03}} Newsweek named B&H as one of America's Top Companies for Customer Service for 2019, with top position in the consumer electronics category based on over 130,000 customer evaluations.{{Cite news|url=https://fstoppers.com/gear/bh-named-top-company-customer-service-newsweek-310556|title=B&H Named Top Company for Customer Service by Newsweek|date=2018-11-22|work=Fstoppers|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}} In 2018, Forbes named B&H as one of America's Best Mid-Size Employers.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/bh-photo-video/#6f56e9b2759c|title=B&H Photo Video on the Forbes America's Best Midsize Employers List|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en}} Also in 2018, B&H's consumer website was recognized as the Best for User Experience of any e-commerce company by the Baymard Institute.{{Cite web|url=https://www.baymard.com/ux-benchmark|title=Top 60 E-Commerce Sites Ranked by UX Performance - Baymard Institute|website=www.baymard.com|access-date=2018-12-03}}
==Ownership and clientele== [[File:Bhphotovideo.JPG|thumb|300px|The exterior of the store on West 34th Street]] B&H Photo Video targets professional [[photographer]]s and [[videographer]]s. Although it is visited by more than 5,000 customers every day from Sunday to Friday, most of the company's business comes from the Internet and corporate sales. It operates a warehouse located in [[Florence, NJ]]. The company carries a wide range of consumer electronics products, with an emphasis on professional and specialty photographic equipment{{Cite web|url=https://www.bhphotovideo.com/find/HelpCenter/AboutUs.jsp|title=About B&H {{!}} B&H Photo Video|website=www.bhphotovideo.com|access-date=2018-12-03}}.{{citation needed|https://www.bhphotovideo.com/find/HelpCenter/AboutUs.jsp=|date=December 2018}} The business owner, Herman Schreiber, and many of the store's employees are observant [[Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)|Satmar]] [[Hasidic Jews]]. The store is closed on [[Shabbat]], most [[Jewish holiday]]s (except for [[Hanukkah]], when business dealings are permitted), and [[Christmas]]. Although the web site remains open, [[e-commerce]] orders are not taken or shipped between Friday evening and Saturday evening, and on Jewish holidays.{{cite web | url = http://www.bhphotovideo.com/ | title = B&H Photo Video |accessdate = May 11, 2010 | quote = Please note that B&H does not process Web orders from Friday evening to Saturday evening.| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100511055443/http://www.bhphotovideo.com/| archivedate= May 11, 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web |url = http://www.bhphotovideo.com/find/SHcalendar.jsp | title = B&H order processing schedule |accessdate = May 11, 2010}} The [[brick and mortar store]] employs hundreds of [[Orthodox Jew]]s as well as many non-Jews. An unaffiliated Orthodox Jewish bus company provides daily service to and from [[Kiryas Joel, New York|Kiryas Joel]], a Satmar village in [[Orange County, New York]], as well as [[Brooklyn]] and [[Queens, New York City|Queens]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/27/nyregion/27orange.html?ex=1314331200&en=87b68618dd591329&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|title=Reverberations of a Baby Boom|author= Santos, Fernanda|date=August 27, 2006}} ==History== B&H opened in 1973 as a storefront film shop at 17 Warren Street in [[Tribeca]], and took its name from the initials of owners Blimie Schreiber and her husband, Herman. Later in the 1970s, B&H moved to a large loft at 119 [[17th Street (Manhattan)|West 17th Street]] between [[Sixth Avenue (Manhattan)|Sixth]] and [[Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)|Seventh]] Avenues in the [[Photo District]] and began to expand its stock to a wider range of film and photography products. In 1997, the store moved to its present location. In addition to photo and video gear, the company offers computers, lighting, audio, TV's, mobile, drones, optics, and more.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bhphotovideo.com/find/HelpCenter/AboutUs.jsp|title=About B&H {{!}} B&H Photo Video|website=www.bhphotovideo.com|access-date=2018-12-03}} It now has more than 2,000 employees.{{cite news|url=http://www.nysun.com/article/48034|newspaper= [[The New York Sun]]|title=B & H Photo Emerges as a N.Y. Institution|author=Karni, Annie|date=February 5, 2007|accessdate=July 8, 2017}} B&H is located just south of [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan]], at 420 [[Ninth Avenue (Manhattan)|Ninth Avenue]] at the intersection with [[34th Street (Manhattan)|West 34th Street]]. In 2007, B&H opened a second floor above its original sales floor making a total of {{convert|70000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of sales space. The first floor sells professional lighting, binoculars, scopes, video, audio, darkroom, film and both home and portable entertainment; the second floor focuses on film and digital photography, computers, printers, tripods, scanners and related accessories. Also in 2007, B&H moved its offices to 440 9th Avenue in Manhattan. As the company has grown, it expanded its office presence to accommodate sales, customer service, buying, marketing, and various back office functions; these functions are housed in 150,000 square feet of office space.{{Cite web|url=https://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20131212/REAL_ESTATE/131219952/japanese-group-pays-210m-for-9th-ave-property|title=Japanese group pays $210M for 9th Ave. property|website=Crain's New York Business|language=en|access-date=November 19, 2018}} In 2007, B&H began making sales through [[Google Checkout]]. The store is noted for having an extensive conveyor belt system that runs along the ceiling.{{cite news|title=Inside B&H conveyor system…|url=http://www.swiss-miss.com/2012/01/inside-bh-conveyor-system.html|accessdate=May 10, 2016|publisher=Swiss Miss}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lense.fr/news/bh-photo-visite-de-la-mecque-des-boutiques-photo/|title=BH Photo: Visite de la Mecque des boutiques photo|first=Par|last=Lâm|date=June 6, 2011|accessdate=July 8, 2017|language=fr}} The store sponsors reviews and events for many tech-savvy websites and tech enthusiast websites including AndroidGuys and Imaging Resource.{{cite news|title=Sony Xperia Z5 review: A sleek and snappy flagship|url=http://www.androidguys.com/2016/05/03/sony-xperia-z5-review-a-sleek-and-snappy-flagship/|accessdate=May 10, 2016|publisher=AndroidGuys|date=May 3, 2016}}{{cite news|title=MindShift’s Multi-Mount Holster lets you match your camera carry style to your active lifestyle|url=http://www.imaging-resource.com/news/2016/05/04/mindshift-multi-mount-holster-match-camera-carry-style-active-lifestyle|accessdate=May 10, 2016|publisher=Imaging Resource|date=May 4, 2016}} In 2015, their [[Google Play]] app was named the "Best Mobile Shopping App" at the [[Mobile Shop Conference]].{{cite news|title=B&H Photo Video Wins Best App of the Year at Mobile Shopping Conference|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/b-h-photo-video-wins-090800063.html|accessdate=May 10, 2016|publisher=Yahoo|date=October 19, 2015}} In 2015, B&H hired SiteSpect, a [[personalization]] platform, to help them with online shoppers.{{cite news|title=B&H Photo gets a clearer picture of online shoppers’ intentions|url=https://www.internetretailer.com/2015/08/24/bh-photo-gets-clearer-picture-online-shoppers-intentions|accessdate=May 10, 2016|publisher=InternetRetailer|date=August 24, 2015|author=Guy, Sandra}}{{cite web|title=@BHPhotoVideo|url=https://twitter.com/BHPhotoVideo|website=Twitter|accessdate=May 10, 2016|author=B&H Photo Video}} B&H often host noted photographers on their podcasts to discuss their books and photos.{{cite news|title=The B&H Photography Podcast Presents: On AIR, an Interview With Vincent LaForet|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/b-h-photography-podcast-presents-213643584.html|accessdate=May 10, 2016|publisher=Yahoo|date=April 14, 2016|author=B&H Photography Podcast}} They have a human operator (or employee) maintaining an active presence on Twitter, YouTube, Facebook, Instagram, and company blogs.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} In 2015, B&H added an [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] authorized shop to the computer department featuring two Apple iconic wooden tables with an assortment of Apple products from [[Macintosh|Macs]], [[iPad]]s to [[Apple Watch]]. There is an Apple employee in shop to assist and consult.{{Cite web|url=http://appleinsider.com/articles/15/03/18/bh-photos-manhattan-superstore-opens-prestigious-apple-authorized-mini-store|title=B&H Photo's Manhattan superstore opens prestigious Apple-authorized mini-store|website=AppleInsider|language=en-US|access-date=July 4, 2017}} In June 2015, B&H Photo offered Apple Pay in its iOS app.{{cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/b-h-photo-app-now-193000467.html|title=The B&H Photo App Now Accepts Apple Pay|date=June 8, 2015|accessdate=July 8, 2017}} In 2016, [[Vaio]] announced that they signed a contract with B&H photo video, to offer their products once again in New York.{{cite news|title=Vaio Expands Distribution With Ingram Micro On Board|url=http://www.twice.com/news/laptops/vaio-expands-distribution-ingram-micro-board/61128|accessdate=May 10, 2016|publisher=Twice|date=April 13, 2016}}{{cite news|title=CORRECTING and REPLACING VAIO® Expands Distribution Channels to B&H Photo Video, DataVision and Ingram Micro|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160412005557/en/CORRECTING-REPLACING-VAIO%C2%AE-Expands-Distribution-Channels-BH|accessdate=July 8, 2017|publisher=BusinessWire|date=April 13, 2016}} In April 2016 B&H Photo announced that they joined forces with CE Week and would be present on the tech show in that June.{{cite news|title=B&H Photo-Video Joins CE Week to Educate Consumers About New CE Devices|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ny-ce-week-idUSnBw245794a+100+BSW20150424|accessdate=May 10, 2016|publisher=Reuters|date=April 24, 2016}}{{cite news|title=B&H Photo Joins Forces with CE Week; Welcomes Attendees to June Tech Show|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/bh-photo-joins-forces-with-ce-week-welcomes-attendees-to-june-tech-show-300243965.html|accessdate=May 10, 2016|publisher=PR Newswire|date=March 31, 2016}}{{cite web|title=What’s New in 2016|url=http://ceweekny.com/2016-about/|website=CE Week|accessdate=May 10, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160522043535/http://ceweekny.com/2016-about/|archive-date=May 22, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=}} In November 2016, B&H Photo offered Apple Pay on mobile web, iOS, and in store.{{cite web|url=https://www.bhphotovideo.com/explora/mobile/news/apple-pay-now-available-bh-mobile|title=Apple Pay Now Available on B&H Mobile|first=Michael|last=Smith|date=}} In May 2018, B&H was named by Forbes Magazine as one of America's Best Midsize Employers for 2018. The Forbes recognition was based on independent employee surveys conducted by Forbes.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/bh-photo-video/#1146bb12759c|title=B&H Photo Video on the Forbes America's Best Midsize Employers List|work=Forbes|access-date=November 18, 2018|language=en}} ==Controversies== In October 2007, it was announced that B&H Photo agreed to pay US$4.3 million to settle allegations that it discriminated against Hispanic workers, while not admitting any wrongdoing.{{cite news |url=http://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/newsroom/release/archive/10-16-07.html |title=EEOC and B & H Reach $4.3 Million Settlement in National Origin Discrimination Case |publisher=[[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] |date=October 16, 2007 |accessdate=November 13, 2007}} In November 2009, a lawsuit against B&H Photo alleged that the store [[Gender discrimination in the United States|refused to hire women]], in violation of New York City and New York State Human Rights Laws.{{cite news |url=http://ny1.com/1-all-boroughs-news-content/top_stories/109168/gadget-retailer-faces-discrimination-suit |title=Gadget Retailer Faces Discrimination Suit |newspaper=[[NY1]] |date=November 19, 2009 |accessdate=November 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091122101612/http://ny1.com/1-all-boroughs-news-content/top_stories/109168/gadget-retailer-faces-discrimination-suit |archivedate=November 22, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The lawsuit, brought by four women, sought class action status on behalf of all women discriminated against by B&H over the course of many years.{{cite news |url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/archives/2009/11/bh_photo_sued_f.php |title=B&H Photo Sued For Talmudic Discrimination Against Women |newspaper=[[Village Voice]] |date=November 19, 2009 |accessdate=November 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091121235418/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/archives/2009/11/bh_photo_sued_f.php |archivedate=November 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Given B&H's prior alleged discriminatory practices, the lawsuit sought US$19 million in compensatory and [[punitive damages]] in order to deter future discriminatory practices.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/19/nyregion/19bagels.html |title=It Was Some Day in Court For Ampersand |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 18, 2009 |accessdate=November 18, 2009 |first=John |last=Eligon |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111111151432/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/19/nyregion/19bagels.html|archivedate=November 11, 2011 |deadurl= no}} In 2011, a lawsuit alleged [[Racism in the United States|discrimination]] against Hispanic workers.{{cite web |last1=Del Signore |first1=John |title=B&H Photo Sued Again For Discriminating Against Employees |url=http://gothamist.com/2011/12/14/bh_photo_sued_again_for_discrimatin.php#. |website=[[Gothamist]] |date=December 14, 2011 |accessdate=June 17, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303214616/http://gothamist.com/2011/12/14/bh_photo_sued_again_for_discrimatin.php#. |archivedate=March 3, 2014 |df= }}{{cite news |last1=Ross |first1=Barbara |title=B and H Photo discriminated against us, say 2 Hispanic employees in lawsuit |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/b-h-photo-discriminated-2-hispanic-employees-lawsuit-article-1.991286 |newspaper=[[New York Daily News]] |date=December 14, 2011 |accessdate=June 17, 2014}} In February 2016 the [[United States Department of Labor]] filed a lawsuit against B&H alleging that the company had only hired Hispanic men into entry-level jobs in a Brooklyn warehouse and then subjected them to harassment and unsanitary conditions.{{cite news |last=McGeehan |first=Patrick |date=February 26, 2016 |title=B&H Electronics Store Sued for Discrimination of Hispanic Workers |url=http://nyti.ms/210VkGX |newspaper=The New York Times }} On August 16, 2017, the company announced that it had settled this matter for a reported $3.22 million.https://petapixel.com/2017/08/16/bh-pay-3-22m-settle-lawsuit-filed-dept-labor/ ==Reviews== In May 2007, [[Zagat]] wrote that B&H offers "more cameras than the paparazzi at the Oscars", with "cordial" staffers who "know their stuff".{{cite web|url=http://brooklyn.ny1.com/content/top_stories/69785/shopping--cameras |title=Shopping: Cameras |last=Simon |first=Stephanie |date=May 16, 2007 |publisher=NY1 |accessdate=April 11, 2010 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927053942/http://brooklyn.ny1.com/content/top_stories/69785/shopping--cameras |archivedate=September 27, 2012 }}{{cite web|title=B&H|url=https://www.zagat.com/s/b-h-photo-video-new-york|website=Zagat|accessdate=May 10, 2016}} In 2016, Consumer Reports awarded B&H Photo its #1 Top Rating for Best Electronics Retailer.{{Cite news|url=https://clark.com/technology/auctions-e-commerce/best-electronics-retailers/|title=Best electronics retailers|date=November 19, 2015|work=Clark Howard|access-date=November 19, 2018|language=en-US}} ==See also== * {{portal-inline|Photography}} * {{portal-inline|New York City}} * {{portal-inline|Business}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{unreferenced|date=April 2015}} The '''China Council for the Promotion of International Trade''' ('''CCPIT''' {{zh|s=中国国际贸易促进委员会|t=中國國際貿易促進委員會|p=Zhōngguó Guójì Màoyì Cùjìn Wěiyuánhuì}}) is a trade body founded in 1952. It also goes by the name of the '''China Chamber of International Commerce''' ('''CCOIC''' 中国国际商会).
The CCPIT develops business cooperation and exchanges with foreign countries. It produces economic data, and is involved with diplomacy and with trade arbitration issues.
==See also== *[[Chamber of commerce]] *[[China International Contractors Association]] *[[China Investment Promotion Agency]], MOFCOM *[[Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce]] *[[China General Chamber of Commerce-U.S.A.]]
==External links== * http://en.ccpit.org/info/index.html [Official site] {{en icon}} * http://www.icc-china.org/ - [[International Chamber of Commerce|ICC]] national committee
{{Economy of China}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:China Council For The Promotion Of International Trade}} [[Category:Chambers of commerce]] [[Category:Foreign trade of China]] [[Category:Auto show organizers]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1952]] [[Category:1952 establishments in China]] [[Category:Investment promotion agencies]]

'''Christian Augustus Henry Allhusen''' (1806–1890) was a [[Danes|Danish]]-[[England|English]] chemical manufacturer based in the North East of England. Born in [[Kiel]] when it was in the Danish Duchy of Holstein, he and his family were displaced when [[Louis-Nicolas Davout|Marshall Davoust]], [[Napoleon]]'s "Iron Marshall," occupied the family home as his headquarters. Allhusen was employed by Koch & Sons, grain merchants of [[Rostock]] and then moved to [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], where he was employed by Campbell & Reveley, also grain merchants.<ref name ="Allen">{{cite book | title = Some Founders of the Chemical Industry: Men to be Remembered | author= John Fenwick Allen | publisher = Sherratt & Hughes | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1GYoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA234&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiThfTx4PHbAhUDOKwKHdFEDLIQ6AEINDAD#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1906 | pages = 231 - 248 | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref> Allhusen became a British citizen by a private Act of Parliament.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Parliamentary Debates (Authorized Edition), Volume 30 | author= | publisher = Wyman| location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ky9VAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT1&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwju0NLn8vHbAhVGL6wKHegaBlk4ChDoAQhVMAk#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1835 | page = | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref> He later went into partnership with [[Henry Bolckow]] and expanded into the ship and insurance brokerage business.<ref name = "Allen"/><ref name ="Joseph">{{cite book | title = The Navigation Laws of Great Britain, Historically and Practically Considered, with Reference to Commercial and National Defence | author= Joseph ALLEN (of Greenwich Hospital.) | publisher = Baily Bros. & James Ridgway | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iPYVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA114&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiKqtm1-PHbAhVPeawKHZeUDm44HhDoAQhWMAk#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1849 | pages = 107 - 112 | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref><ref name ="Reid">{{cite book | title = Middlesbrough and Its Jubilee: A History of the Iron and Steel Industries, with Biographies of Pioneers | author= Sir Hugh Gilzean-Reid | publisher = "The Gazette" Printing and Publishing Offices | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iPYVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA114&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiKqtm1-PHbAhVPeawKHZeUDm44HhDoAQhWMAk#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1881 | pages = 113 - 114 | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref>
In 1840, Allhusen purchased a soap works in [[Gateshead]], and began the manufacture of chemicals, eventually calling the company C. Allhusen & Sons. In 1871, Allhusen converted his enterprise into a [[joint-stock company]], Newcastle Chemical Works, Ltd. He made a large fortune, and was influential in the region as company director and shareholder in such companies as the Northumberland & Durham District Bank, the Newcastle & Gates Water Company and the Consett Iron Works. He was an active member of the Newcastle Chamber of Commerce and the Tyne Commission.<ref name = Allen/>
In 1854, Allhusen was among local industrialists urging construction of a new [[Wharf|quay]] for Gateshead. When the quay was eventually constructed, the local government failed to include necessary transportation facilities to allow efficient transport to and from the quay facility. As a result, the quay complex required years of subsidies and struggled to avoid failure as Allhusen had predicted.<ref>{{cite book | title = North East England, 1850-1914: The Dynamics of a Maritime-industrial Region | author= Graeme J. Milne| publisher = Boydell Press | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=wbkV5FL8ygAC&pg=PA96&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwifjuSZ8PHbAhVIZKwKHSq2BHMQ6AEIVDAJ#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false| date = 2006 | page = 96 | isbn = 9781843832409 | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref>
Allhusen died January 13, 1890 at Stoke Court, [[Buckinghamshire]].<ref>{{cite book | title = Chemist and Druggist, Volume 36 | author= | publisher = Benn Brothers | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=alU9AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA61&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwju0NLn8vHbAhVGL6wKHegaBlk4ChDoAQgmMAA#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1890 | page = 61 | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==See also== *''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', Allhusen, Christian Augustus Henry (1806–1890), chemical manufacturer by N. G. Coley, rev.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Allhusen, Christian Augustus Henry}}

{{Infobox Prime Minister | name =Constantin Argetoianu | nationality =[[Romania]]n | smallimage = | image =Argeto.jpg | imagesize =170px | caption = | order =41st [[Prime Minister of Romania]] | term_start =28 September 1939 | term_end =24 November 1939 | monarch =[[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]] | vicepresident = | deputy = | predecessor =[[Gheorghe Argeşanu]] | successor =[[Gheorghe Tătărescu]] | order2 = | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | birth_date = 15 March 1871 | birth_place =[[Craiova]], [[Romania]] | death_date ={{death date|1955|2|6|mf=y}} (aged 83) | death_place =[[Sighet]], [[Romania]] | constituency = | party =[[National Renaissance Front]] | spouse = | profession =businessman | religion =[[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian Orthodox]] | signature = | footnotes = |}} '''Constantin Argetoianu''' ({{OldStyleDate|15 March|1871|3 March}} – 6 February 1955) was a [[Romania]]n politician, one of the best-known personalities of [[Interwar period|interwar]] [[Greater Romania]], who served as the [[List of Prime Ministers of Romania|Prime Minister]] between 28 September and 23 November 1939. His [[memoirs]], ''Memorii. Pentru cei de mâine. Amintiri din vremea celor de ieri'' ("Memoirs. For those of tomorrow. Recollections of yesterday's world")—a cross section of Romanian society, were made known for the sharp critique of several major figures in Romanian politics (using a sarcastic tone which had made his previous political speeches notorious).<ref>Otu; Slabey Roucek, p.76</ref>
==Biography==
===Early life=== Born in [[Craiova]] as the son of [[Romanian Army|Army]] general [[Ioan Argetoianu]], he trained in Law, Medicine, and Letters at the [[University of Paris]], and later entered the diplomatic service (1897).<ref name="Slabey Roucek, p.76">Slabey Roucek, p.76</ref>
He was an exceptionally prosperous man (a noted [[Bucharest Stock Exchange|Stock Exchange]] player and landowner in [[Breasta]], [[Dolj County]]), and his frequent change in political allegiances was attributed by some of his contemporaries to his financial independence.<ref name="Savu; Slabey Roucek, p.76">Savu; Slabey Roucek, p.76</ref> He served as a [[combat medic]] with the rank of captain in the [[Second Balkan War]], where he faced a [[cholera]] epidemic.<ref>Manolache</ref>
===World War I===
A [[Freemasonry|Freemason]],<ref>Otu</ref> Argetoianu was first elected to the [[Senate of Romania|Senate]] in 1914 as a [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880-1918)|Conservative Party]] representative,<ref name="Savu; Slabey Roucek, p.76"/> where he oscillated between the dissident the mainstream Conservatives of [[Petre P. Carp]] and the dissident group around [[Take Ionescu]] (the latter was welcoming Romania's entry into [[World War I]] on the side of the [[Allies of World War I|Entente Powers]], which Argetoianu also proposed).<ref>Boia, p.251</ref>
Throughout 1918, during the final stages of the [[Romanian Campaign (World War I)|Romanian Campaign]], Argetoianu was Justice Minister, sitting on the first [[Alexandru Averescu]] cabinet (at the time when authorities had retreated to [[Iaşi]], leaving the southern half of the country to be occupied by [[German Empire|Imperial German]], [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] and [[Bulgaria]]n troops).<ref name="Slabey Roucek, p.76"/> He was also head of the Romanian delegation at the Peace preliminaries of [[Buftea]], in 1918. The talks resulted in the [[Treaty of Bucharest, 1918|Treaty of Bucharest]] of May, which consecrated Romania's defeat by the [[Central Powers]]. His actions at the time were later the subject of an [[epigram]] by [[Cincinat Pavelescu]] (Pavelescu expressed his belief that the treaty and Argetoianu's views on fiscal policies were to be the subject of scorn for future generations).<ref>Pavelescu</ref>
===People's Party=== Argetoianu followed Averescu into opposition to the [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]] [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL) cabinet, and joined the [[People's Party (interwar Romania)|People's Party]] (PP) created by the latter. He later documented the [[Populism|populist]] message of the movement, and left testimonies of Averescu's spontaneous adulation by the crowds of peasants.<ref>Boia, p.264; Scurtu, "Prăbuşirea unui mit", "Mit şi realitate..."</ref>
Argetoianu was Finance Minister and later [[List of Romanian Ministers of the Interior|Interior Minister]] in the second Averescu government of 1920.<ref>Slabey Roucek, p.76; Troncotă, p.18</ref> In March 1921, it was uncovered that an associate of his named Aron Schuller had attempted to contract a 20 million [[Italian lira|lire]] loan with a bank in [[Italy]], using as [[Collateral (finance)|collateral]] Romanian [[war bond]]s that he had illegally obtained from the Finance Ministry reserve.<ref>Constantinescu, p.68</ref> Argetoianu, who was still in charge at the time, became the target of attacks from the opposition group formed by the [[Romanian National Party]] and the [[Peasants' Party (Romania)|Peasants' Party]], being pressed by [[Virgil Madgearu]] and [[Grigore Iunian]] to explain himself (Iunian proposed a [[motion of no confidence]], but the PNL continued to show its support for the PP).<ref>Constantinescu, p.68–70</ref>
===Clash with Communism and split with Averescu=== Argetoianu soon became noted for his [[Anti-Communism|anti-communist]] stance: he carried out arrests of those [[Socialist Party of Romania|Socialist Party]] members who, during their party's congress in May 1921, supported a [[Maximum programme|maximalist platform]] and voted in favor of aligning their Socialist-Communist faction (future [[Romanian Communist Party|Communist Party of Romania]]) with the [[Comintern]], citing the latter's condemnation of [[Greater Romania]] (all those arrested were prosecuted in the [[Dealul Spirii Trial]]).<ref>Diac; Troncotă, p.18–19</ref> Argetoianu later stated that the arrest lacked legal grounds, and indicated that he purposely gave the Socialist [[Gheorghe Cristescu]] approval to hold the congress as a means to incriminate the faction.<ref name="Diac">Diac</ref> Faced with mixed reactions inside the cabinet (Averescu hesitated, while the Minister of Justice [[Grigore Trancu-Iași]] refused to give him support), he ordered the move without his fellow ministers' prior knowledge, and thus faced them with a ''[[fait accompli]]''.<ref name="Diac"/>
The standoff between Averescu and the parliamentary opposition eventually witnessed a decisive incident: during a prolonged debate over Averescu's proposal to [[Nationalization|nationalize]] enterprises in [[Reşiţa]], Argetoianu addressed a mumbled insult to Madgearu; the PNL, seeing an opportunity for a return to power, expressed sympathy, and all opposition groups appealed to Ferdinand, asking for Averescu's recall (July 14, 1921).<ref name="Scurtu, Prăbuşirea unui mit">Scurtu, "Prăbuşirea unui mit"</ref>
Despite Averescu's eventual defeat in December 1921, Argetoianu was kept in office by the [[Take Ionescu]] and Brătianu cabinets. During the spring of 1922, he ordered the killing of several Communist activists who were held in prison custody, including [[Leonte Filipescu]], staging their attempts to flee from under escort as a pretext.<ref>Troncotă, p.18–19</ref> Nevertheless, pressures on the revolutionary grouping were relaxed in summer, when [[King of Romania|King]] [[Ferdinand I of Romania|Ferdinand I]] approved an [[amnesty]] and Argetoianu officially declared that "communism is over in Romania".<ref>Argetoianu, in Diac; in Troncotă, p.19</ref>
===PND and PNL=== In 1923, after Brătianu again assumed power, he clashed with Averescu and proclaimed himself leader of the PP, being eventually expelled.<ref name="Scurtu, Prăbuşirea unui mit"/> Having joined [[Nicolae Iorga]]'s [[Democratic Nationalist Party (Romania)|Democratic Nationalist Party]] (PND), he soon vehemently protested against the latter's alliance with the Romanian National Party, and moved to the PNL.<ref name="Slabey Roucek, p.76"/>
Following the sudden death of Ion I. C. Brătianu in 1927, and choosing, in contrast to the policies of [[Dinu Brătianu]], to support the new King [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]] in 1930, Argetoianu left the party and subsequently defined himself as an independent.<ref name="Slabey Roucek, p.76"/> In effect, he moved into the camp of politicians approving of an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] regime around Carol.<ref name="Veiga, p.130">Veiga, p.130</ref> As the monarch's relations with the traditional political class were souring, Argetoianu allegedly engaged in a campaign to draw new allegiances from other environments, aiding to establish a Romanian ''[[Camarilla (history)|camarilla]]'' — it was even reported that, using the official commitment to neutral [[Technocracy (bureaucratic)|technocracy]] as a means to appoint his choice of people to positions of influence, he had recruited his fellow [[Bucharest]] [[Jockey Club of Bucharest|Jockey Club]] members.<ref name="Veiga, p.130"/> Among his most vocal supporters at the time was the [[far right]] philosopher [[Nae Ionescu]].<ref>Ornea, p.226; Veiga, p.200</ref>
===Iorga cabinet and Agrarian Party=== He was again in charge of Internal Affairs and Finance from 1931 to 1932, during the Iorga government,<ref>Slabey Roucek, p.76; Veiga, p.137–138</ref> when he took a harsh stance against the [[Fascism|fascist]] [[Iron Guard]], outlawing it and arresting some of its members (which led to a string of violent confrontations).<ref>Ornea, p.295, 296; Veiga, p.137</ref> Argetoianu was hotly contested as Finance Minister: faced with the widespread [[insolvency]] of small agricultural holdings in front of the [[Great Depression]], he proposed a form of [[liquidation]] that was considered in breach of the [[1923 Constitution of Romania|1923 Constitution]].<ref>Veiga, p.130, 140–141</ref> Various other issues forced Argetoianu to cease payments of salaries for [[Civil service|civil servants]] at certain intervals, causing far-reaching problems.<ref>Veiga, p.156</ref>
The government was voted out of office in the elections of 1932, when Iorga was replaced by [[Alexandru Vaida-Voevod]], a member of the [[National Peasants' Party]] (PNŢ) who was himself challenged with solving the agrarian issue;<ref>Veiga, p.138, 141</ref> Argetoianu subsequently founded the minor [[Agrarian Union Party]], which, after the National Liberals returned to power with [[Ion G. Duca]], remained a close associate of the king in his competition with traditional forces; when Duca was assassinated by the Iron Guard in the final days of 1933, Argetoianu, together with his former adversary, PNŢ dissident [[Grigore Iunian]], and the [[National Agrarian Party (Romania)|National Agrarian Party]]'s [[Octavian Goga]], was probably one of the king's main options in his attempt to create an altogether new political establishment around the ''camarilla'', relying on a compromise with [[Corneliu Zelea Codreanu]] (leader of the Iron Guard).<ref>Veiga, p.202, 209, 215</ref> Codreanu refused to accept negotiation, but Carol successfully approached the PNL's "young liberals" faction, which came to power with [[Gheorghe Tătărescu]] (January 1934).<ref>Veiga, p.202</ref>
===Royal dictatorship and World War II=== The frequent target of attacks in the Iron Guard press,<ref>Ornea, p.243, 245</ref> Argetoianu led his grouping until 1938, when, faced with the unstoppable rise of the Iron Guard, Carol banned all parties and established his [[National Renaissance Front]] (FRN).<ref>Argetoianu, "Pleacă Tătărescu, vine Gigurtu"; Veiga, p.215</ref>
His own short-lived FRN cabinet, established after that date, was, after [[Gheorghe Argeşanu]]'s the second in quick succession to the violent clash between the Guard and monarch (after the murder of [[Armand Călinescu]] by the former). The Argetoianu government was replaced by that of Tătărescu, who had to deal with the [[Soviet Union]]'s [[Soviet occupation of Bessarabia|occupation of Bessarabia]] and was in turn replaced with [[Ion Gigurtu]]<ref>Argetoianu, "Pleacă Tătărescu, vine Gigurtu"</ref> (Argetoianu, who remained influential throughout the period, began calling for a rapprochement between Romania and the Soviets).<ref name="ReferenceA">Otu</ref>
Carol's regime crumbled after the [[Second Vienna Award]], when Romania had to cede [[Northern Transylvania]] to [[Hungary]]; it was replaced by the Iron Guard's [[National Legionary State]], which, itself repressed during the previous years, began a campaign of retaliation — like Tătărescu and several others, Argetoianu was kidnapped on November 27, 1940 in the wake of the [[Jilava Massacre]], and faced assassination until being rescued by the intervention of [[Romanian Army]] officials.<ref>Veiga, p.292, 309</ref>
Retreating from public life during [[World War II]] and the [[Ion Antonescu]] dictatorship (''see [[Romania during World War II]]''), Argetoianu left the country in the spring of 1944, settling in [[Switzerland]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Romania's withdrawal from the [[Axis Powers|Axis]] and the start of [[Soviet occupation of Romania|Soviet occupation]] caused him to return in November, seeing an opportunity in the apparent decrease in the appeal of traditional parties and expanding on his vision of Romanian-Soviet cooperation.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> He was the subject of derision in the [[National Peasants' Party]] press (''[[Dreptatea]]'' wrote of him: "leading the intrigue in favor of a [[private property]]–based [[communism]], a [[Capitalism|capitalist]]-based [[socialism]], a [[Working class|mass]]-free [[democracy]]... The country is trustingly placing itself at your disposal. Here are your strings: pull them! Here are your back rooms: maneuver them! Here is your «people»: take it away!").<ref>"Profilo", in Otu</ref>
===UNMR, arrest, and death===
Attempting in vain to mediate between the Communists and the PNȚ, Argetoianu was rejected by both sides, and, in January 1947, formed his own grouping — the ''National Union for Work and Reconstruction'' (''Uniunea Națională Muncă și Refacere'', UNMR) —, alongside [[Nicolae Ottescu]], [[Nicolae D. Cornățeanu]], [[Zamfir Brătescu]] and others.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> It was kept under surveillance by the Communist-controlled [[Petru Groza]] government, and was infiltrated by the pro-Communist ''National-Agrarian Action'' (''Acțiunea Național-Agrară'', ANA).<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The UNMR disbanded over worries that Argetoianu was losing credibility with Soviet authorities—the group around Cornățeanu joined Premier Groza's [[Ploughmen's Front]], while others entered the [[Union of Patriots (Romania)|Union of Patriots]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Argetoianu, who was ill at the time and had just undergone surgery on his [[prostate]], withdrew from public life for a second time.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Two years after a [[Communist Romania|Communist regime]] was imposed on Romania, on the morning of May 6, 1950, he was arrested by the [[Securitate]]; while being taken away, he was heard saying: "Man, you sure are tough, you communists, if you are afraid of a farting old man such as myself".<ref>Argetoianu, in Otu</ref> He died in the infamous [[Sighet prison]] five years later,<ref>* {{citation | last = Giurescu | first = Constantin C. | year = 1994 | title = Cinci ani și două luni în penitenciarul din Sighet (7 mai 1950 – 5 iulie 1955) | publisher = Editura Fundației Culturale Române | place = București }}</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Neagoe | first = Stelian | year = 2012 | title = Politică și destin. Constantin Argetoianu | publisher = Editura Machiavelli | authorlink = Stelian Neagoe |place= București }}</ref> never having been put on trial. In 1999, attorney and civil rights activist [[Monica Macovei]], representing Argetoianu's two granddaughters - Yvonne Oroveanu Niculescu and Constantina "Dina" Oroveanu - before court cleared Argetoianu of all charges, with prosecutor Carp admitting that Argetoianu's detention had been an abuse.<ref>{{citation | date = 1999 | title = A încetat urmarirea penală împotriva fostului prim-ministru Constantin Argetoianu | newspaper = Evenimentul Zilei | url = http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/a-incetat-urmarirea-penala-impotriva-fostului-prim-ministru-constantin-argetoianu-567864.html | accessdate = August 8, 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140330193854/http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/a-incetat-urmarirea-penala-impotriva-fostului-prim-ministru-constantin-argetoianu-567864.html | archivedate = March 30, 2014 | df = }}</ref>

'''Decision Model and Notation''' ('''DMN''') is a standard published by the [[Object Management Group]].<ref name="DMNstandard">OMG standard "Decision Model and Notation (DMN)", [http://www.omg.org/spec/DMN current version]</ref> It is a standard approach for describing and modeling repeatable decisions within organizations to ensure that decision models are interchangeable across organizations.
The DMN standard provides the industry with a modeling notation for decisions that will support [[decision management]] and [[business rules]]. The notation is designed to be readable by business and IT users alike. This enables various groups to effectively collaborate in defining a [[decision model]]: * the business people who manage and monitor the decisions, * the [[business analyst]]s or [[functional analyst]]s who document the initial decision requirements and specify the detailed decision models and decision logic, * the technical [[Software developer|developer]]s responsible for the automation of systems that make the decisions.
The DMN standard can be effectively used standalone but it is also complementary to the [[BPMN]] and [[CMMN]] standards. BPMN defines a special kind of activity, the Business Rule Task, which "provides a mechanism for the process to provide input to a business rule engine and to get the output of calculations that the business rule engine might provide"<ref>OMG standard "BPMN", [http://www.omg.org/spec/BPMN/Current current version]</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Purchase|first1=Jan|title=Book Review: Process and Decision Modeling in BPMN/DMN|url=http://blog.luxmagi.com/2015/01/book-review-process-and-decision-modeling-in-bpmndmn/|website=Decision Management for Finance Blog|publisher=Lux Magi Ltd|accessdate=19 April 2015|date=January 5, 2015}}</ref> that can be used to show where in a BPMN process a decision defined using DMN should be used.
DMN has been made a standard for Business Analysis according to [[BABOK]] v3.<ref>{{cite book|last1=IIBA|title=A Guide to the Business Analysis Body of Knowledge® (BABOK® Guide)|date=April 15, 2015|isbn=978-1927584026|pages=512|edition=3rd}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Decision Modeling now standard for Business Analysts|url=http://jtonedm.com/2015/04/28/decision-modeling-now-standard-for-business-analysts/}}</ref>
== Elements of the standard == The standard includes three main elements * Decision Requirements Diagrams that show how the elements of decision-making are linked into a dependency network. * Business context for decisions such as the roles of organizations or the impact on performance metrics. * A Friendly Enough Expression Language (FEEL) that can be used to evaluate expressions in a decision table and other logic formats.
== Use cases == The standard identifies three main use cases for DMN * Defining manual decision making * Specifying the requirements for automated decision-making * Representing a complete, executable model of decision-making
== Benefits == Using the DMN standard will improve business analysis and business process management, since * other popular requirement management techniques such as [[BPMN]] and UML do not handle decision making * growth of projects using business rule management systems or [[BRMS]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mann|first1=Stephanie|title=Business rules management: Tools, techniques for success|url=http://www.ebizq.net/topics/business_rules_management/features/13351.html|website=ebizq.net, The Insider's Guide to Next-Generation BPM|accessdate=19 April 2015}}</ref> which allow faster changes<ref>Discovering the Decisions within Your Business Processes using IBM Blueworks Live, [https://books.google.be/books?id=OhzCAgAAQBAJ Publisher IBM Redbooks, 2014] {{ISBN|0738453579}}</ref> * it facilitates better communications between business, IT and analytic roles in a company<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ronen|first1=Gil|last2=Feldman|first2=Jacob|title=Decision models using dmn and bpmn standards: mortgage recommender|url=http://www.slideshare.net/gilnyc/decision-models-using-dmn-bpmn-standards-mortgage-recommender?related=2|website=Slideshare|publisher=OpenRules}}</ref> * it provides an effective requirements modeling approach for [[Predictive Analytics]] projects and fulfills the need for "business understanding" in methodologies for advanced analytics such as [[CRISP-DM]] * it provides a standard notation for decision tables, the most common style of [[business rules]] in a [[BRMS]]
== Relationship to BPMN ==
DMN has been designed to work with [[BPMN]]. [[Business process model]]s can be simplified by moving process logic into decision services. DMN is a separate domain within the OMG that provides an explicit way to connect to processes in BPMN. Decisions in DMN can be explicitly linked to processes and tasks that use the decisions. DMN expects that the logic of a decision will be deployed as a stateless, side-effect free Decision Service. Such a service can be invoked from a business process and the data in the process can be mapped to the inputs and outputs of the decision service.
== DMN BPMN example == As mentioned, [[BPMN]] is a related [[Object Management Group#OMG Standards|OMG Standard]] for process modeling. DMN complements [[BPMN]], providing a separation of concerns between the decision and the process. The example here describes a BPMN process and DMN DRD (Decision Requirements Diagram) for onboarding a bank customer. Several decisions are modeled and these decisions will direct the processes response.
===New bank account process=== In the BPMN process model shown in the figure, a customer makes a request to open a new bank account. The account application provides the account representative with all the information needed to create an account and provide the requested services. This includes the name, address and various forms of identification. In the next steps of the work flow, the 'Know Your Customer' (KYC) services are called. In the 'KYC' services, the name and address are validated; followed by a check against the international criminal database (Interpol) and the database of persons that are 'Politically exposed persons ([[Politically exposed person|PEP]])'. The PEP is a person who is either entrusted with a prominent political position or a close relative thereof. Deposits from persons on the PEP list are potentially corrupt. This is shown as two services on the process model. Anti-money-laundering (AML) regulations require these checks before the customer account is certified. [[File:DMN_NewBankAccountProcess_BPMN.jpg|thumbnail|Figure: A process with decisions for creating a new bank customer.]]
The results of these services plus the forms of identification are sent to the Certify New Account decision. This is shown as a 'rule' activity, verify account, on the process diagram. If the new customer passes certification, then the account is classified into onboarding for Business Retail, Retail, Wealth Management and High Value Business. Otherwise the customer application is declined. The Classify New Customer Decision classifies the customer. If the verify-account process returns a result of 'Manual' then the PEP or the Interpol check returned a close match. The account representative must visually inspect the name and the application to determine if the match is valid and accept or decline the application.
===Certify new account decision=== [[File:DMNCertifyNewA_DRG.jpg|thumbnail|The decision structure logic and data associated with the account verification.]]
An account is certified for opening if the individual's' address is verified, that valid identification is provided, and that the applicant is not on a list of criminals or politically exposed persons. These are shown as sub-decisions below the 'certify new account' decision.The account verification services provides a 100% match of the applicants address. For identification to be valid, the customer must provide a driver's license, passport or government issued ID.
The checks against PEP and Interpol are 'Fuzzy' matches and return matching score values. Scores above 85 are considered a 'match' and scores between 65 and 85 would require a 'manual' screening process. People who match either of these lists are rejected by the account application process. If there is a partial match with a score between 65 and 85, against the Interpol or PEP list then the certification is set to manual and an account representative performs a manual verification of the applicant's data. These rules are reflected in the figure below, which presents the decision table for whether to pass the provided name for the lists checks. [[File:DMN_pass_excluded_names_table_cropped.png|thumbnail|Business rules for evaluating the score of the PEP and Interpol 'Fuzzy' match.]]
===Client category=== The client's on-boarding process is driven by what category they fall in. The category is decided by the: * Type of client, business or private * The size of the funds on deposit * And the estimated net worth This decision is shown below: [[File:DMN_client_category_DRG.jpg|thumbnail|The client category decision.]] There are 6 business rules that determine the client's category and these are shown in the decision table here: [[File:DMN_client_category_table.jpg|thumbnail|A DMN decision table with business rules for classifying a customer into a category based on the input data.]]
===Summary example=== In this example, the outcome of the 'Verify Account' decision directed the responses of the new account process. The same is true for the 'Classify Customer' decision. By adding or changing the business rules in the tables, one can easily change the criteria for these decisions and control the process differently.
Modeling is a critical aspect of improving an existing process or business challenge. Modeling is generally done by a team of business analysts, IT personnel, and modeling experts. The expressive modeling capabilities of BPMN allows business analyst to understand the functions of the activities of the process. Now with the addition of DMN, business analysts can construct an understandable model of complex decisions. Combining BPMN and DMN yields a very powerful combination of models that work synergistically to simplify processes.

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2016}} {{BLP sources|date=September 2015}} '''Dimitris Kontominas''' ({{lang-el|Δημήτρης Κοντομηνάς}}); born 1939) is a Greek businessman who is active in insurance, television, cinema and retail trade. He has one daughter and two grandchildren.
==Early life==
He was born on June 3, 1939 in [[Athens]]. He studied at the [[American University of Beirut]]. Initially he worked as insurer in ''American Life (ALICO)''. In 1969, he cofounded with Alexander Tampoura the insurance company ''Interamerican''.<ref name=Interamerican>{{cite web|title=Founding of interamerican|url=http://www.interamerican.gr/?pid=10&la=2|website=Interamerican}}</ref> Interamerican now belongs to Eureko BV. Kontominas remained chairman until 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.invgr.com/interamerican_Kontpminas_eureko_divorce.htm |title=INVgr / Dimitris Kontpminas steps down as Chairman of Interamerican, to sell 3.3% of Eureko |work=invgr.com }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Kontominas owns Prime Insurance and MyDirect insurers. He founded or acquired other companies, including: * ''Interbank'' (later acquired and absorbed by Eurobank) * ''Intertech''<ref name=Reuters>{{cite web|title=Intertech Officer from reuters|url=http://in.reuters.com/finance/stocks/officerProfile?symbol=ITTr.AT&officerId=926761}}</ref> (exclusive representative products ''Panasonic'') * Euroclinic Athens * ''Novabank (in'' 2006 renamed ''Millennium Bank'') * ''InterJet'' – aircraft and helicopter fleet * ''GreenFarm'' * ''FC Aris'' * [[Alpha TV]] and radio station ''Alpha 98.9'' (66% held by January 2012, the German group RTL) * ''Village Roadshow Greece'' theaters * Athens/Thessaloniki Channel 9 and radio station ''Alpha 96.5 Radio'' in Thessaloniki
In 2012 Kontominas took back the shares of Alpha TV<ref>{{cite web|url=http://csridentity.com/luxembourg/rtlgroup.asp |title=RTL Group |work=csridentity.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118041541/http://csridentity.com/luxembourg/rtlgroup.asp |archivedate=November 18, 2015 |df=mdy }}</ref> when RTL Group decided to exit. In 2015 Alpha TV was the number one Greek TV station.
Kontpminas is the president of DEMCO GROUP, one of Greece's largest investment holding companies. It has a diversified portfolio, with holdings in media, financial services, entertainment, IT and telecom, leisure and Entertainment and Food & Beverages. Within its companies' portfolio one can find Village Group (Cinema and films), Alpha TV and Alpha Radio, Intertech (Panasonic's exclusive representative in Greece), Prime Insurance, myDirect online insurance, ''Sportday'' newspaper and many more.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.demco.gr/|title=home|work=demco.gr}}</ref> For a little time in the early 2000s was owner of [[Aris F.C.]].
He declared "Great Protekdikos Archon of the Ecumenical Throne"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ec-patr.org/gr/offik/List.htm | title=Ονομαστικός Κατάλογος των Αρχόντων Οφφικιάλων της Μεγάλης του Χριστού Εκκλησίας}}</ref> from the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople and "Great Benefactor" from Metropolis of Chalcedon.Aris F.C.
He was arrested in 2014. According to the authorities approximately 200 million euros worth of loans were issued by the bank during the period in question to companies controlled by certain well-connected businessmen without guarantees, none of which have been repaid. The case is also linked to another financial scandal involving another 300 million worth of losses due to bad loans made to a property developer. The accused face charges including fraud, money laundering and complicity in malpractice. An extremely scandalous man, no one refers to the money he stole from Greeks living abroad while he was owner of Interamerican. The story hit the media in 2004 by a rivalry channel Alter owned by Nikos Kouris. The channel does not exist anymore and the Interamerican Scandal is nowhere to be mentioned.

{{POV|date=February 2018}} '''Dominik Florian Brunner''' (born 18 May 1959 in [[Stuttgart]], died 12 September 2009 in [[Munich]]) was a [[Germany|German]] businessman. He was the CFO of Erlus AG, Germany’s largest [[roof tile]] manufacturer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bild.de/BILD/news/bild-english/world-news/2009/09/16/munich-s-bahn-train-death/killer-teen-gang-let-go-six-days-before-attack.html|author1=J. Völkerling |author2=S. Kiener |author3=J. Ley |author4=S. Arbinger |author5=S. Kürthy |author6=B. Wittmann |author7=D. Steinbach |title=Killer teen S-Bahn gang were let go six days before deadly attack|date=2009-09-16|work=bild.de|accessdate=2009-10-07}}</ref> He was killed in a fight which resulted from Brunner trying to protect a group of school children from attacks by teenagers.
==Biography== Brunner was born to a family of entrepreneurs. His father, Oscar Brunner, was the finance manager of one of Germany's largest roof tile manufacturers, Erlus AG. After receiving his [[Abitur]] in [[Landshut]], Brunner studied law at the [[University of Munich]] and worked in office positions in [[San Francisco]] and Paris. He followed in his father's footsteps when he took a leading position at Erlus AG. His fields of responsibility included finance, organization, personnel, law and purchases.
In the 1990s, Brunner trained in [[kickboxing]] at Boxclub Straubing, but gave up the hobby after he noticed more and more young men arriving at the club to learn how to beat others.<ref name=diezeit>Claudia Keller, [http://www.zeit.de/politik/2010-07/schlag-auf-schlag-70092?page=all "Das Heldenbild Brunner wird unheimlich"], ''[[Der Tagesspiegel]]'', ''[[Die Zeit]]'', 12 July 2010, retrieved 1 November 2012 {{de icon}}</ref>
==Death== On 12 September 2009, four school children were being threatened on a [[Munich S-Bahn]] train by two older teenagers, Markus Schiller and Sebastian Leibinger,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/0714/1224274660976.html|title=Youths on trial for killing 'Samaritan'|author=Derek Scally|date=14 July 2010|work=[[Irish Times]]|accessdate=29 July 2010}}</ref> who tried to rob and mug them. When Brunner and the young teens arrived at [[München Solln station]], Brunner was punched and kicked over 20 times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://open.salon.com/blog/lost_in_berlin/2009/09/20/death_of_a_hero_the_murder_of_dominik_brunner|title=Death of a hero: The murder of Dominik Brunner|date=2009-09-20|author=Alan Nothnagle|work=Lost in Berlin, Open Salon blog|publisher=salon.com|accessdate=2009-10-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007142929/http://open.salon.com/blog/lost_in_berlin/2009/09/20/death_of_a_hero_the_murder_of_dominik_brunner|archivedate=2009-10-07|df=}}</ref> He eventually died on-site due to a pre-existing heart condition.<ref>http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/justiz/0,1518,707012,00.html</ref>
Schiller and Leibinger were charged with murder.<ref name=diezeit/> In the court case, it was proven that Brunner became involved with the aim of protecting the school children, but questions were raised as to whether he died due to the brutal beating by the accused, and there were differing versions of how the fight between Brunner and the accused started.<ref name=diezeit2/> When the accused were threatening the children, Brunner asked them to stop, or he would call the police. The accused did not listen, so Brunner informed the police. He then asked the children to "stay away", took up a combat position and started to hit and fight the accused. However, according to another witness, Brunner approached the accused, shouted "this is what you want", and then hit Markus Schiller in the face. Although he was described as a hero in early media reports, there was discussion later regarding how much blame for starting the fight lies with Brunner himself.<ref name=diezeit2>Miriam Hollstein, [https://www.welt.de/vermischtes/weltgeschehen/article8509029/Ist-Dominik-Brunner-jetzt-noch-ein-Held.html "Ist Dominik Brunner jetzt noch ein Held?"] ''Die Welt'', 18 July 2012, retrieved 1 November 2012 {{de icon}}.</ref>
The court pronounced judgement on 6 September 2010: Schiller, who had by then turned 19, was sentenced to 9 years and 10 months in a youth facility as a primary accomplice in an attempted robbery with violence leading to murder; Leibinger was sentenced to 7 years in a youth facility as a primary accomplice in an attempted robbery with violence leading to grievous bodily harm resulting in death.<ref>[http://www.justiz.bayern.de/gericht/olg/m/presse/archiv/2010/02740/ Strafverfahren gegen Markus S. und Sebastian L. wegen Mordes u. a. (S-Bahnhof Solln)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203001743/http://www.justiz.bayern.de/gericht/olg/m/presse/archiv/2010/02740/ |date=December 3, 2013 }}, Press release, Oberlandsgericht München, Justiz in Bayern, 6 September 2010 {{de icon}}</ref> The [[Federal Court of Justice of Germany|Federal Court of Justice]] rejected the defence appeal.<ref>[http://www.augsburger-allgemeine.de/bayern/Urteil-gegen-Haupttaeter-im-Brunner-Prozess-ist-rechtskraeftig-id17008616.html "Urteil gegen Haupttäter im Brunner-Prozess ist rechtskräftig"], ''[[Augsburger Allgemeine]]'', 5 October 2011, retrieved 1 November 2012 {{de icon}}</ref>
==Awards== Brunner was posthumously awarded the [[Bavarian Order of Merit]] (''Bayerischer Verdienstorden'') by [[Minister-President]] of Bavaria [[Horst Seehofer]], and the [[Federal Cross of Merit]] by [[German President]] [[Horst Köhler]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thelocal.de/national/20091005-22359.html|title=President honours man killed by bullies at Munich S-Bahn station|date=2009-10-05|work=thelocal.de|accessdate=2009-10-07}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.dominik-brunner-stiftung.de/ Dominik Brunner Stiftung für Zivilcourage] (established by his relatives)
{{Authority control}}

[[File:Downtown Palatka 035.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Downtown Palatka]] '''Downtown Palatka''' is the [[central business district]] of [[Palatka, Florida|Palatka]], [[Florida]]. According to the Palatka Community Redevelopment Agency, the district is bounded by Main Street to the north, Laural Street to the south, the [[St. Johns River]] to the east, and Eleventh Street to the west, Historical Fort Shannon was located at the east end of downtown on the river, near what is today City Hall. <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.southernhistory.us/Counties/c4putn.htm |title= Putnam County |publisher= Chris Kimbell |date= |accessdate= March 28, 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111002155401/http://www.southernhistory.us/Counties/c4putn.htm |archivedate= October 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Area transportation is conducted by [[Ride Solution]] and connects downtown passengers to other core areas in Putnam County.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.theridesolution.com/ |title= Putnam County Routes |publisher= Ride Solution |date= |accessdate=March 28, 2011}}</ref>
'''Public offices and services''' located in the downtown area: * Palatka City Hall * Palatka Gas Authority * Palatka Housing Authority * Palatka Police Department * Palatka Post Office * [[Palatka (Amtrak station)|Palatka Union Depot]] * Putnam County Chamber of Commerce * [[Putnam County Courthouse (Florida)|Putnam County Courthouse]] * Putnam County School Board
==Arts and culture==
The downtown area contains important local cultural landmarks such as the [[Larimer Memorial Library| Larimer Arts Center]], Tilghman House, [[Bronson-Mulholland House]], and the [[Palatka (Amtrak station)|David Browning Railroad Museum]]. Downtown also plays host to local festivals and events including, the [[Florida Azalea Festival]], Blue Crab Festival, and [[Mug Race]]. Numerous other public gathers occur throughout the year. Murals have become a common sight on the streets of downtown. Headed by the Conlee Mural Committee, the group has transformed numerous building walls into works of art.
==Governance==
Downtown Palatka, Inc. is a non-profit organization that represents area merchants and promotes local events in the downtown area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.palatkadowntown.com/about-dpi.html |title= About DPI |publisher= Downtown Palatka, Inc. |date= |accessdate=March 28, 2011}}</ref> Palatka Community Redevelopment Agency is an organization established in 1983 to oversee the revitalization of downtown and the historic districts. Issues of concern to the agency include the presence of substandard or inadequate structures, a shortage of affordable housing, inadequate infrastructure, insufficient roadways, and inadequate parking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://palatka-fl.gov/?page_id=25 |title= Community Redevelopment Agency|publisher= City of Palatka |date= |accessdate=March 28, 2011}}</ref>
==Historic Lemon Street==
[[File:Downtown Palatka 021.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Lemon Street Sign]] Technically, Lemon Street is the portion of St. Johns Avenue that extends into Downtown Palatka. The tree lined street serves as the main shopping district in the city. The area has made strides in becoming a 24-hour neighborhood, with new restaurants, bars and other establishments opening in recent years. During large events vehicular traffic is diverted and the street acts as the main pedestrian-way, housing vendors and entertainment.
== Surrounding neighborhoods == *[[Palatka North Historic District]] *[[Palatka South Historic District]] *[[Palatka Heights]] *[[Newtown (Palatka)|Newtown]] *[[East Palatka, Florida|East Palatka]]

{{globalize|date=October 2007}} A '''facilitating payment''' is a certain type of payment to foreign officials that is not considered to be [[bribery]] according to [[legislation]]s of some states as well as in the international anti-bribery conventions, e.g., coming from the [[OECD]].
==Dangers== For legal purposes, it is distinguished from [[bribery]], however the distinction is often blurred.<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/business/opinion/is-facilitating-payment-a-bribe-or-not-758043 "Is 'facilitating payment' a bribe or not?"], ''Business Report'', September 8, 2004</ref> Determining whether a payment is a facilitating one may be difficult and depend on the circumstances. The value of the payment is not immediately relevant, however the greater the value, the higher are chances that it will be a [[red flag (signal)|red flag]] for law enforcement. Small unofficial payments are customary and even legal in some countries, nevertheless they may present a risk of liability according to the laws of the host country. There also exists a [[slippery slope]] danger of evolving into dubious payments.<ref name=deming/>
==Business ethics== While being legal, facilitating payments are still considered to be questionable from the point of view of [[business ethics]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Argandoña|first1=Antonio|title=Corruption and Companies: The Use of Facilitating Payments|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|date=September 2005|volume=60|issue=3|pages=251–264|doi=10.1007/s10551-005-0133-4}}</ref><ref>Bailes, Robert (2006). Facilitation Payments: Culturally Acceptable or Unacceptable Corrupt? ''[[Business Ethics: A European Review]]'', 15(3), 293-298.</ref> The following arguments have been made: *[[Unfair competition]]: smaller business have fewer opportunities and less financial possibilities to "grease" foreign officials. *sustaining questionable business practices.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rdoger|first1=Raliigh|title=Ways to improve international business payment solutions|url=http://www.transferguru.com/blog/9-ways-improve-your-international-business-payment-solutions/|website=www.transferguru.com|accessdate=3 March 2017|language=en|date=4 January 2014}}</ref> *dependence on irregular payments creates additional risk and hence discourages investment<ref name=walters/>
Many companies therefore restrict or severely limit making facilitating payments in their policies, however this practice is not yet widespread. For example, {{As of|2006|lc=on}}, in [[Australia]], among the [[S&P ASX 100]] only 24 companies control facilitating payments and only 15 are reported to prohibit them.<ref name=walters>[http://www.allbusiness.com/management-companies-enterprises/1188858-1.html "Just how is business done? A review of Australian business's approach to bribery and corruption"], by Julie Walters, ''Keeping Good Companies'', July 1, 2006</ref>
==Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development== [[OECD]] defines a payment to be a facilitating one if it is paid to government employees to speed up an administrative process where the outcome is already pre-determined.<ref name=walters/>
==By country== ===Australia=== {{As of|2006}}, the [[Australia]]n law has discrepancies as to the definition of the facilitating payment.
The Criminal Code defines a facilitating payment to be a payment which is <ref name=walters/> * of a nominal value (the term is not defined in the Code) * paid to a foreign official for the sole or predominant purpose of expediting a minor routine action, and * documented as soon as possible.
The [[Income Tax Assessment Act]] as amended in 1999 permit companies claim facilitation payments as deductions (before 1999 bribes were also valid deductions), but its definition does not refer to the size of the payment.<ref name=walters/>
Many Australian states override the federal legislation and define facilitating payments as illegal.<ref name=walters/>
===Russia=== In Russia this phrase (in English) means payment to a bureaucrat when he does off-job extra work for a private entity by helping deal with his ministry. It is generally unclear whether it has a part of corruption in it. It was generally considered legal, until economy minister [[Ulyukaev]] received 8 years jail for it. After this case, Russian bureaucrats are reported to heavily refrain from this practice.
===United Kingdom=== {{As of|2010}}, subsequent to the Bribery Act, the [[United Kingdom]] does not recognize the legality of facilitating payments and does not draw any distinction from bribes. However the OECD notes that the UK is unlikely to prosecute for minor facilitating payments in the areas where it is a common practice. The Ministry of Justice guidance, however, confirms that prosecutors will exercise discretion in determining whether to prosecute. In addition, informal guidance received from the SFO indicate that where it is considering action, it will be guided by the following six principles: * Whether the company has a clear and issued policy. * Whether the company has written guidance available to employees as to the procedures they must follow where a facilitation payment is requested or expected. * Whether such procedures are really being followed (monitoring). * Evidence that gifts are being recorded at the company. * Proper action, collective or otherwise, to inform the appropriate authorities in countries when a breach of the policy occurs. * The company is taking what practical steps it can to curtail such payments.<ref name=walters/>
===United States=== Within the [[United States federal legislation]], a '''facilitating payment''' or '''"grease payment"''', as defined by the [[Foreign Corrupt Practices Act]] (FCPA) of 1977 and clarified in its 1988 amendments, is a payment to a foreign official, political party or party official for "routine governmental action", such as processing papers, issuing permits, and other actions of an official, in order to expedite performance of duties of non-discretionary nature, i.e., which they are already bound to perform. The payment is not intended to influence the outcome of the official's action, only its timing.<ref name=deming>Stuart H. Deming (2005) The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act And the New International Norms", American Bar Association, {{ISBN|1-59031-326-7}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=ITG208fCRvcC&pg=PA15&lpg=PA15&dq=%22facilitating+payment%22&source=web&ots=aAgWUfUiD4&sig=2zCEc0NNJwgL-GSgPosF0xCxJTU p.15]</ref> Facilitation payments are one of the few exceptions from anti-[[bribery]] prohibitions of the law.
==Evolution of the notion== Prior to the 1988 amendments, the exclusion of "grease payments" was via the definition of the "foreign official", which did not include persons without discretionary (decision-making) duties, e.g., ones with clerical functions. The major drawback of this approach is that often it is difficult to properly identify the scope of duties of a foreign official. The 1988 amendment eliminated this drawback by placing the emphasis on the purpose of the payment rather than on the duties of the recipient. At the same time the scope of the "routine governmental actions" in question was made sufficiently narrow and supplied with detailed examples.<ref>Don Zarin (1995) "Doing Business Under The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act", Practising Law Institute {{ISBN|0-87224-087-8}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=bv8jACUiP74C&pg=PT4&vq=facilitating&dq=%22facilitating+payment%22&sig=WLtZd_725SOmPExCTH8MP-fRvMs#PPT114,M1 $5.1]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Facilitating Payment}} [[Category:Ethically disputed business practices]] [[Category:Business law]] [[Category:United States federal legislation]]
